ELDRIDGE CALLS
OUT CANDIDATES
Men in their first, second or
third years are urged to try
out for the position of assistant manager of basketball.
John Eldridge, the present
manager, has recently made
known such vacancies. Those
interested are requested to report to Carlin's Wednesday or
Thursady afternoon at 4.15
P.M.

SECOND COTILLON
ON FEBRUHRY 5
John Eldridge, President of
the Cotillon Club, has announced the second cotillon on
the evening of February 5.
The Maryland Casualty Ball
Room will be the scene of the
affair. The price this time will
be $2.50 per couple or $1.50
stag, a decided reduction in
comparison to the fee charged
for the first aeair.

YOUNGER COLLEGE MEN
ON RECENT WESTINGHOUSE JOBS

The "Triumph"and"Defiance"
Where do young college men get in a large
industrial organization? Have they
opportunity to exercise creative talent?
Is individual work recognized?

EEN -VISAGED seamen
who watch the foam swirl in
of the "Triumph" and
wake
the
"Defiance," U.S. Shipping Board
vessels, see in these ships somedling more than cargo-carriers.
'These staunch boats are emblems
of American enterprise on the
high seas.
To gain economy
in their competition
with fpreign-owned

K

marine units these ships were
recently converted from steam
to Diesel-Electric drive—the
highest powered Diesel-Electric
ship installations thus far developed. Direct electric propulsion
of 4.000 hp. at a propeller speed
of 6o rpm. was provided, and
the auxiliary equipment was also
electrified. An important byproduct of the conversion was a
valuable increase in the total
available cargo - carrying space.

The big jobs go to organizations
with the resources and facilities
to handle them. Westinghouse
attracts young men of enterprise
and genius because it daily provides
interesting opportunities such as
smaller concerns can seldom offer.
f

The huge propulsion motors of the
"Triumph" and "Defiance" arc of the
double armature type designed to maintain high efficiency at low propeller
speeds. The installations include electric motors for blowers, windlass, oil
and water pumps, and
warping winches — a
complete modern marine electrification by

estinghouse

Westinghouse.

8395 (eight thousand three hundred

YOUNGER COLLEGE MEN
ON RECENT WESTINGHOUSE JOBS

The "Triumph"and"Defiance"
Where do young college men get in a large
industrial organization? Have they
opportunity to exercise creative talent?
Is individual work recognized?

EEN -VISAGED seamen
who watch the foam swirl in
of the "Triumph" and
wake
the
"Defiance," U.S. Shipping Board
vessels, see in these ships somedling more than cargo-carriers.
'These staunch boats are emblems
of American enterprise on the
high seas.
To gain economy
in their competition
with fpreign-owned

K

marine units these ships were
recently converted from steam
to Diesel-Electric drive—the
highest powered Diesel-Electric
ship installations thus far developed. Direct electric propulsion
of 4.000 hp. at a propeller speed
of 6o rpm. was provided, and
the auxiliary equipment was also
electrified. An important byproduct of the conversion was a
valuable increase in the total
available cargo - carrying space.

The big jobs go to organizations
with the resources and facilities
to handle them. Westinghouse
attracts young men of enterprise
and genius because it daily provides
interesting opportunities such as
smaller concerns can seldom offer.
f

The huge propulsion motors of the
"Triumph" and "Defiance" arc of the
double armature type designed to maintain high efficiency at low propeller
speeds. The installations include electric motors for blowers, windlass, oil
and water pumps, and
warping winches — a
complete modern marine electrification by

estinghouse

Westinghouse.
